author: RT en Fran√ßais
title: Frappes isra√©liennes au Liban : plus de 70 000 personnes contraintes de quitter leur foyer ‚Äî RT en fran√ßais
text: Frappes isra√©liennes au Liban : plus de 70 000 personnes contraintes de quitter leur foyer Le ministre libanais de l'Int√©rieur, Bassam Maoulaoui, a annonc√© ce 26 septembre que 70 100 personnes avaient √©t√© d√©plac√©es en raison des attaques isra√©liennes au Liban. Elles sont actuellement r√©parties dans 533 centres d'h√©bergement √† travers le pays, tandis que plus de 13 000 Syriens ont quitt√© le Liban pour regagner leur pays. √Ä ce jour, 70 100 personnes d√©plac√©es en raison des agressions isra√©liennes au Liban ont √©t√© officiellement enregistr√©es, r√©parties sur 533 centres d'h√©bergement √† travers le pays, a annonc√© ce 26 septembre le ministre libanais de l'Int√©rieur, Bassam Maoulaoui. Lors d'une conf√©rence de presse tenue au si√®ge du minist√®re √† Beyrouth, le ministre a indiqu√© que le d√©partement de l'Int√©rieur, en collaboration avec les autorit√©s comp√©tentes, ≈ìuvrait afin de garantir la s√©curit√© des personnes vuln√©rables, y compris les malades et les personnes √† mobilit√© r√©duite parmi les d√©plac√©s. Le responsable libanais a √©galement soulign√© que des efforts √©taient d√©ploy√©s pour les accueillir dans des centres d'h√©bergement adapt√©s, r√©pondant ainsi √† leurs besoins sp√©cifiques en cette p√©riode de crise humanitaire. Plus de 640 morts depuis le 23 septembre ¬´Notre r√©ponse concerne les Libanais d√©plac√©s, mais nous sommes au c√¥t√© de chaque personne dans le besoin, et il existe des centres d‚Äôh√©bergement dans la B√©kaa destin√©s aux Syriens¬ª, a-t-il pr√©cis√©. De fait, ¬´13 500 Syriens ont quitt√© le Liban en direction de la Syrie¬ª. Bassam Maoulaoui a soulign√© que le minist√®re de l'Int√©rieur participerait √† des r√©unions publiques et maintiendrait un contact permanent avec les gouverneurs afin d'√©valuer les besoins des personnes d√©plac√©es. Les agressions isra√©liennes ont contraint pr√®s de 83 100 personnes √† abandonner leur foyer. Depuis le 23 septembre, l'arm√©e isra√©lienne a d√©clench√© une offensive d√©crite comme la ¬´plus violente, la plus √©tendue et la plus intensive¬ª contre le Liban depuis le d√©but des hostilit√©s avec le Hezbollah, il y a environ un an. Cette escalade tragique a d√©j√† fait 640 morts, dont 50 enfants et 95 femmes, et 2 505 bless√©s.

author: Sid Natividad
title: Miami Concert Fan Kicks Another Man Several Rows Down the Stadium in Morgan Wallen Tour, 'He Has the High Ground!' | The Nerd Stash
text:
Concerts are meant to be loud and rowdy, but a Morgan Wallen Tour concert, which took place in Miami, Florida, got a little too riotous thanks to two guys. One of the guys even recklessly kicked another man, sending him tumbling several rows down the stadium and ruining the concert for others.
The incident happened during Morgan Wallen‚Äôs ‚ÄúI‚Äôm the Problem‚Äù tour in Hard Rock Stadium, Miami Gardens, Florida, back on July 12. For the concert, Morgan Wallen used a side of the stadium, and an altercation between two men took place in the nosebleed seats of the stadium section.
It‚Äôs not clear what led to the altercation, but the man who assaulted the other fan in front of him started by kicking him down, which sent him a couple of rows back. Angry at his assailant, the fallen fan climbed back up row-by-row, only to be kicked down again by the same assailant, and this time, he came tumbling further down at around four rows.
Other fans were notably angry and frustrated since the concert was in full swing, and some viewers have even noticed that the kick was well-timed to the chorus or an important part of the song. Sadly, the video was cut too early, and we likely won‚Äôt see how the other man fared, especially after falling down a steep row of hard plastic chairs.
Some Climbs Aren‚Äôt Worth It
People online were quick to point out how unwise it was to put yourself in the same disadvantageous position after getting kicked by someone higher up. Some have compared the situation to a pop culture meme from Star Wars, namely Obi-Wan‚Äôs famous high-ground scene with Anakin.
‚ÄúLiterally when he started going back up, I was like ‚ÄòNo, don‚Äôt, he has the high ground!'‚Äù recalls sideshowbvo
‚ÄúDude as he‚Äôs climbing back up ‚ÄòYou underestimate my power‚Äô üòÇü§£,‚Äù jokes Professional_Run_817
Though despite the more lighthearted reactions that seem to have minimized the man‚Äôs injury, the altercation could very well result in a battery case and even a lawsuit, as there‚Äôs clear video evidence of the assault. Others couldn‚Äôt help but notice how steep the seats were and how painful the man‚Äôs fall could be, especially if he hit his head or hit other Miami concert-goers along the way.
‚ÄúHe really choose the perfect moment on that last kick. Man dropped 4 rows. Those seats are so steep, that would be terrible,‚Äù worries Informal-Force-4030
‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a great setup to get your neck broken,‚Äù according to Raumfalter
Hopefully, the man who initiated the assault gets the punishment he deserves, because kicking or shoving someone from a great height could‚Äôve easily endangered several people, especially in a public event, and no amount of verbal disagreements warrants such a reaction.

author: , Gadsden Times
title: SEC Softball Tournament weather updates: Thursday's games delayed by weather
text: The 2024 SEC Softball Tournament was delayed Thursday at Auburn's Jane B. Moore Field due to inclement weather. The quarterfinal round of the tournament was scheduled to begin at 11 a.m. CT, but the SEC posted on X (formerly known as Twitter) at 10:24 a.m. that it would be going into a rain delay. At 10:55 a.m., the account said they were under an "extended delay . The Tennessee Vols X account called the delay an "indefinite rain delay" and that the next update would come at 1 p.m. CT. LSU-Tennessee will be played at 5 p.m. Thursday, followed by Missouri-Arkansas 35 minutes after the conclusion of that game. Florida-Georgia will be played at 9 a.m. Friday, with Texas A&M and South Carolina following it up 35 minutes after.Here‚Äôs what you need to know about the SEC softball schedule and the latest updates: REQUIRED READING: SEC Softball Tournament bracket: Full TV schedule, scores, results for 2024 championship [SEC Tournament softball weather updates] 4:08 p.m.: The Tennessee Vols softball social media account posted a picture for sore eyes: A view of the sun. It looks like everything should be on track to get in two softball games in the SEC Tournament tonight. An 3 p.m., the social account tweeted out a video of the players exiting the team bus and getting prepared for the 5 p.m. contest. 1:05 p.m.: The SEC social media account tweeted out a revised schedule for the quarterfinal. Tennessee-LSU will play at 5 p.m. CT, followed by Missouri-Arkansas 35 minutes following the conclusion of the first game. Florida-Georgia will be moved to Friday morning, with a 9 a.m. first pitch. Texas A&M and South Carolina will play 35 minutes following the conclusion of that one. 12:53 p.m.: At 12:50 p.m. CT, the LSU softball account tweeted that the first pitch of the Tennessee-LSU game is now scheduled for 5 p.m. CT. With three other games scheduled behind the quarterfinal opener, it will be interesting to see how the schedule plays out. 12:01 p.m.: The SEC Softball Tournament remains in an "extended weather delay", per the SEC social media account. There are no updates yet about a potential start time. SEC softball tournament schedule for quarterfinals The 2024 SEC Tournament got underway Tuesday with No. 13 seed Ole Miss beating No. 12 Kentucky 7-2. Four games were played in the second round Wednesday, including 14-inning victories for 8 seed LSU over 9 seed Alabama and 7 seed Georgia over 10 seed Auburn. Tennessee, which is the No. 1 overall seed and the defending champion, was scheduled to open the day against LSU at 11 a.m. Here's a look at the rest of the scheduled games for the rest of the day: - Game 6: No. 1 Tennessee vs. No. 8 LSU | 5 p.m. | SEC Network - Game 7: No. 4 Arkansas vs. No. 5 Missouri ‚Äì approx. 35 minutes following Game 6 | SEC Network - Game 8: No. 2 Florida vs. No. 7 Georgia ‚Äì 9 a.m., Friday | SEC Network - Game 9: No. 3 Texas A&M vs. No. 11 South Carolina ‚Äì approx. 35 minutes following Game 8 | SEC Network The semifinals are scheduled to begin at 4 p.m. Friday, and the championship game is scheduled for 5 p.m. Saturday.

Coffee Meets Bagel and Bumble appear to be on the rise as well, however in terms of large volume, Tinder, PoF, Match and Badoo seem like the greatest gamers in the existing dating app video game.

title: God gives His servants a second chance - Tribune Online
text: WE have all made mistakes in our lives, falling short of God‚Äôs glory. However, the good news is that God is a God of second chances.

author: Craig LaBan
title: Ogawa Sushi & Kappo is a contender for Philly's next great omakase
text:
A well-marbled tuna belly or vivid orange tray of Hokkaido sea urchin are the expected luxuries that drive the big spenders to fill several of the various omakase counters across Philadelphia . But lately, I‚Äôve come to relish the suspense of wondering what comes next. One moment I‚Äôve savoring the impressive richness of kama tuna cut from the well-toned jaw of a bluefin, the next thing I know sushi chef Carlos Wills reaches under the counter at Ogawa Sushi & Kappo and unfurls a four-foot-long red fish with a slender bill on its face that looks like the love child of an eel and a platypus.
The ‚Äúmystery fish box‚Äù that produced this garden hose of a fish ‚Äî known as a red cornetfish, or yagara, it is related to the seahorse, has no scales, and vacuums up its prey at twilight in the warm waters of Japan‚Äôs coral reefs ‚Äî is one of the great pleasures of eating a top-notch omakase. This is the assortment of often rare, in-season fish from Japan that some of the best sushi counters in the States receive on a regular basis from their seafood purveyors as a sort of bargain bonus buy. The contents are never announced beforehand, the quantities are small, and the varieties are ever-changing.
This clearly wasn‚Äôt Wills‚Äô first yagara rodeo. With the brilliant flash and steady glide of his polished long knife, it took only a few minutes for him to disassemble the beast into perfectly uniform slices of white fish to be draped over tiny balls of lightly warmed rice delicately seasoned with vinegar. The flavor was decidedly subtle and pleasantly nutty, even buttery, but it was the unique texture wowed me: Its flesh was firm to the initial bite, reflecting its off-the-bone-freshness, before it became as fluffy as a cotton ball.
Advertisement There are a number intriguing omakase options in Philadelphia these days , most notably Royal Sushi & Izakaya, where chef Jesse Ito has become a perennial finalist for the James Beard award . As noted in my recent review, Royal Sushi remains the city‚Äôs gold standard for a blow-out sushi feast. But as Ito‚Äôs tasting becomes even more impossible to book, the question of who‚Äôs next in line becomes a pressing pursuit.
Queen Village‚Äôs minimalist Sakana and the polished hush of Hiroki in Fishtown have each made their case to be Philly‚Äôs luxury omakase Plan B, while Yuhiro‚Äôs u-maki handroll bar is fun, and the speedy 15-course, one-hour omakase at Kichi ‚Äî where I found the rice to be mushy and the gold spray bling a cheap trick ‚Äî are vying for the bargain tasting set. I will follow the peripatetic Kevin Yanaga wherever he totes his knives, but his eponymous new ‚ÄúJapanese Dive Bar‚Äù in Northern Liberties is still too new for me to have visited yet.
Now Ogawa Sushi & Kappo , a local spin-off from a sushi mainstay of the Washington D.C. scene, is making its case with a $200 menu featuring some of the highest quality fish around, presented in the minimalist edomae sushi style, a traditionalist approach that eschews the Americanized distractions of colorful sauces and overly complicated rolls in favor of fish (often sourced from Tokyo Bay) molded around rice distinctly seasoned with vinegar. With family connections and monthly reconnaissance trips to Japan by owner-chef Minoru Ogawa, whose brother still operates Ko Sushi, the family‚Äôs 70-year-old restaurant in Tokyo, Ogawa‚Äôs Philly outpost has already distinguished itself as a source for some of the most distinctive offerings around. (In fact, since their delivery trucks from New York stop in Philly first, our fish is at least 90 minutes fresher than what diners get in D.C.)
During my first visit, there was a sailfin poacher, or hakkaku, a spiny fish with a dorsal fin that looked like it could fly, and flesh that was both crunchy and sweet. There was a snappy red blood clam, lightly torched Japanese barracuda, and my first-ever encounter with octopus eggs, which tasted sort of like a briny, sticky rice pudding in a bowl topped with salmon eggs and a raw quail yolk for triple egg intensity.
My second visit was even better, not only because the talented young Wills ‚Äî a sushi pro for eight years despite being just 23 ‚Äî has come from D.C. to take-up semi-permanent residence behind the counter, but because Ogawa had finally begun to gel into the semblance of a complete experience. The service is overseen by co-owner and managing partner, Vy ‚ÄúVee‚Äù To, a a naturally warm host who is a financial advisor by day. There‚Äôs also solid sake service and an admirable starter collection of Japanese whiskies that can quickly escalate the already considerable fee of $200 plus beverage, tip and tax.
My expectations were admittedly guarded based on the set-up. I‚Äôd eaten a completely forgettable lunch at Ikki, the sushi restaurant that preceded Ogawa in its Old City space. The narrow bi-level room lined with ribbed wooden walls still has as much charm as an airport lounge. No doubt, chef Ogawa brings a well-reviewed reputation from DC . But his local partners don‚Äôt exactly have a destination dining pedigree. Vee has never worked in a restaurant before, while her other partners (and neighbors) own Kabuki, a quick-serve sushi and ramen spot wedged between a bail bond office and a parking lot near City Hall where the generic fish and overly dry grains of flavorless rice were so disappointing at a recent lunch, it wasn‚Äôt worth the $20 ‚Äî a tenth of the price of a meal at Ogawa.
Dinner here feels more relaxed and convivial than several other omakases I‚Äôve experienced, and there‚Äôs been a reliably diverse crowd that offers a down-to-earth Philly rebuke to the obnoxious ‚Äúbromakase‚Äù clich√© recently decried in the New York Times , which declared the growing national omakase trend the ‚Äúnew steakhouse‚Äù corporate power meal . I even recognized from a recent meal at Royal Sushi some women at the end of Ogawa‚Äôs counter as part of a group of friends who share their standing reservations at some local favorites.
Interestingly, chef Ogawa‚Äôs partner, Yumiko Stegner, says that D.C. customers are far more conservative compared to Philly diners, ‚Äúwho love surprises.‚Äù Wills, a Honduran immigrant who‚Äôs been working in D.C. sushi restaurants since he was 15 (hanging after school with his sushi chef dad), is happy to oblige with the ever-changing the 23-course tasting.
The $200 meal combines cooked food with sashimi and multiple rounds of nigiri, and while none of the compositions are intricate, each one showcases beautiful ingredients or technique. I‚Äôve had tuna tartare with sea urchin before, but Wills serves this first bite inside a crispy rice cup topped with soy sauce that has been hand-whisked with dashi and egg whites into a pale brown foam, an old-time trick by Ogawa-san to stretch a key ingredient. Sweet white Alaskan shrimp shimmer inside the chilled umami of amber-colored dashi jelly. Chawanmushi takes on beefy luxury of wagyu tartare, hijiki black seaweed and white truffle oil.
A series of crab dishes celebrated a crustacean spring. The bodies from softshell crab tempura are steeped into the next course‚Äôs miso soup, which in turn gets topped with sawagani, the tiny, lively river crabs we saw scuttling around in a bucket before they were brought to the kitchen and reappeared deep-fried just moments later, perched atop the miso soup bowl like a crunchy orange snack of crab-shaped popcorn. Later, the sweet white threads of painstakingly picked seiko kani, Japanese runner crab, came pressed around nigiri rice jeweled with its own tiny orange eggs.
Wills‚Äô sushi, meanwhile, brought a series of memorable slices draped over vinegar-tanged rice, from the dusky sweetness of a female mantis shrimp to two kinds of flounder, including a barfin variety he butchered before us whole to accentuate its firmer snap and richer flavor. A pristinely cut sashimi plate brought multiple hues and degrees of bluefin tuna richness alongside a thick curl of orange ocean trout and the lean elegance of a translucent white opaleye (mejina) topped with crunchy fronds of red seaweed.
There was A5 wagyu torched until it glistened with fat, which was supplemented with more from goose foie gras; a sweet scallop dusted in black soy salt; and a grilled ocean eel glazed in a sweet dark sauce Wills had boiled down from the bones of the butchered fish that was far more delicate than saccharine coating often seen in unagi preparations.
Along the way, with a mixed tartare handroll, a fluffy tamago-yam souffl√© and finally a dessert of steamed tres leches custard, Vee and her team paired the meal with generous pours of excellent sakes from Dassai 45, Amabuki Ichigo, and Tenko 40. A beautiful, albeit shockingly pricy ($65) single-malt from Akashi aged in sherry casks seemed like a perfect way to finish a satisfying splurge meal ‚Äî and also hint at spirits to come.
Ogawa‚Äôs Philly team has taken its evolution slowly. Vee has drawn valuable mentorship from fellow restaurateurs Ellen Yin and Ange Branca, as well as Drexel‚Äôs Jonathan Deutsch, to help improve the natural flow of hospitality. (It‚Äôs worked). Ogawa also recently added some luxe take-out options that offer more accessibility than its omakase, which serves only 18 diners over the course of two seatings a night.
But the next step will be more exciting: a small izakaya on its mezzanine floor with 15 seats, a limited food menu (wagyu hot dogs, miso wings) and a Japanese-themed cocktail menu being designed by mixologist and James Beard award-winning author of Slow Drinks , Danny Childs. Set to debut sometime in August, this will be ‚Äúthe city‚Äôs first true Slow Drinks beverage program,‚Äù says Childs, with ‚Äúthe focus on hyperlocal and hyperseasonal ingredients that are able to tell the story of both the mid-Atlantic United States and Japan.‚Äù A barley shochu highball made with barley tea from Deer Creek Malthouse ? A Kaki Daisy made with American persimmons grown and foraged in Childs‚Äô South Jersey backyard? I cannot wait to taste them, along with more surprises to come. That, after all, is part of what has made Ogawa such a worthy newcomer to begin with.

author: latercera.com
title: Canciller√≠a entrega nota de protesta a Venezuela
text:
Alonso Aranda Hace 2 horas Tiempo de lectura: 1 minuto Ar√©valo M√©ndez Romero, embajador de Venezuela en Chile. Ar√©valo M√©ndez acudi√≥ la tarde de este jueves al Ministerio de Relaciones Exteriores, donde sostuvo un encuentro privado con representantes nacionales. El anuncio de la comunicaci√≥n diplom√°tica fue realizada horas antes por el Presidente Gabriel Boric, quien se√±al√≥ que ‚ÄúChile es un pa√≠s serio, en donde las instituciones funcionan, y en donde la Fiscal√≠a y el Ministerio P√∫blico est√°n llevando una investigaci√≥n seria, responsable‚Äù.
compartir Comentarios En horas de la tarde de este jueves, en dependencias del Ministerio de Relaciones Exteriores fue entregada la nota de protesta a Venezuela por los dichos del fiscal general de ese pa√≠s, Tarek William Saab, en torno al crimen del teniente (R) Ronald Ojeda Moreno.
La herramienta comunicacional diplom√°tica fue entregada al embajador de Venezuela en Chile, Ar√©valo M√©ndez Romero, quien sostuvo un encuentro con representantes de la Canciller√≠a.
Diputados de oposici√≥n califican nota de protesta contra Venezuela insuficiente y llaman a Boric a ser ‚Äúm√°s duro‚Äù Toh√° afirma que el gobierno recurrir√° a ‚Äúorganismos multilaterales‚Äù para manifestar su molestia tras dichos de fiscal venezolano El anuncio de la nota de protesta la hizo el propio Presidente Gabriel Boric en esta jornada ante los medios de comunicaci√≥n en La Moneda.
El Mandatario dijo que instruy√≥ al canciller, Alberto van Klaveren , para hacerla llegar a trav√©s de los canales diplom√°ticos, defendiendo que ‚ÄúChile es un pa√≠s serio, en donde las instituciones funcionan, en donde hay separaci√≥n de poderes, y en donde la Fiscal√≠a y el Ministerio P√∫blico est√°n llevando una investigaci√≥n seria, responsable‚Äù.
La historia continua m√°s abajo
M√°s sobre Canciller√≠a Canciller (s) dice que esperar√°n respuesta de Venezuela a nota de protesta para definir llamado a embajador en Caracas Hace 1 hora Quintana (PPD) afirma que dichos de fiscal venezolano son ‚Äúuna notificaci√≥n de que no quieren colaborar‚Äù en el caso Ojeda Hace 11 horas ‚ÄúPor lo tanto, si desde otro organismo en particular de la Fiscal√≠a venezolana tienen antecedentes serios, reales, los tienen que poner a disposici√≥n de la Fiscal√≠a chilena ‚Äù, se√±al√≥ el Jefe de Estado.
Cabe consignar que la m√°xima autoridad de la Fiscal√≠a venezolana se√±al√≥ que el homicidio y secuestro del exmilitar y disidente del gobierno de Nicol√°s Maduro, Ojeda Moreno , pudo ser ejecutado por ‚Äúcuerpos de inteligencia de Chile y extranjeros‚Äù como una ‚Äúoperaci√≥n de falsa bandera‚Äù.
Seg√∫n informaron desde el Minrel, esta tarde la canciller (s) Gloria de la Fuente dar√° un punto de prensa en el que se espera que se refiera a la entrega de la nota de protesta y al estado de las relaciones diplom√°ticas con Venezuela.
